title: MakerFarm Prusa i3v Hexagon Bulldog Lite Print Fan Auto Bed Leveling X-Carriage

description.text:
Edit: FYI, you should print this with ABS and high infill percentage. My PLA version ended up warping and melting when I tried printing higher temps. I uploaded a new version, v3, which adds a hole for an inductive auto bed leveling sensor and changes the geometry of the fan duct so you don't have to trim it after.

I have a MakerFarm 8'' Prusa i3v with a Bulldog Lite extruder and Hexagon hotend. Apparently, this is a very unique configuration because I can't find any other parts to work with it. I needed a print fan for PLA printing, so I decided to integrate it all into an X-Carriage mount. The difference was like night and day for PLA prints. I did need to trim the end of the fan duct a little bit to allow me to install and remove the hotend more easily, but that isn't reflected in this model.

Printer:

MakerFarm Prusa i3v 8''

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

50% or higher

Notes:

Supporting this while printing was a little tricky. I actually ended up needing to tape it together during the print to allow it to finish. I used 20% infill, but it's a little too bendy for my liking, so I'd recommend doing higher, even 100% infill if you have the time. I printed with white 1.75mm PLA.

author: djmx

description.text:
I needed a way to test a prototype of an adjustable cylindrical lens required to help people with astigmatism in 3rd world countries. Using 7 lasers allows me to test the complete range of the lens while being able to find the focal point(s). However, a professional laser box easily exceeds $150.

This mount allows you to calibrate 7 laser modules with a diameter of 6mm.

This only works with low power lasers due to the low melting point of PLA. When using higher power laser modules, consider using PLA.

Hourglass shape so laser ray can be moved up and down by adjusting the screws another section view Width is 6mm so laser can only move up and down

The model has been designed in Solidworks 2016 educational version

Tolerances
.5mm

Features
Laser has to be able to rotate
Laser can be adjusted up and down
Laser can be fixed in mount
Mount can be mounted

Step 1:
Mount the laser bracket and let them shine on a piece of paper normal to the laser array.

Step 2:
Draw 7 lines with a distance of 12mm in between. (Image 1)

Step 3:
Rotate the laser modules so every laser is projected on the corresponding line. (Image 1)

Step 4:
Adjust screws to align all rays on one line

Image 1 - After rotating the lasers Image 2 - After adjusting the screws

14 M3x15mm screws
7 6mmx15mm Laser diodes
5V 200+mA Power Supply

comments.text: Here's my 5x3 laser holder in Tinkercad. I printed this last night, but I'll wait to test it with lasers before I post a remix to Thingiverse. The lasers I have on hand are the plastic body type that are larger than 6mm.

comments.text:
Great design! I'm going to try to use your Solidworks file to make a five-laser version of this. Have you thought of how to do two or even three rows of lasers on top of each other?
One idea: Make the screws short enough so another row could sit on top using pieces of threaded rod for attachment at left and right.
Another idea: make a staggered (staircase) holder for three of these things.
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text: The stair design sounds like a good option since laser beams are parallel it doesn't really matter some laser rays start a bit further away. However, I used this design to test the quality of a adjustable lens so we took multiple pictures of the lens with the array at different positions to test the complete range of the lens. I don't really see a use for multiple rows of laser arrays but it would sure look cool :)
comments.author: CaptObvious

comments.text:
Thanks for the suggestion! Thanks for sharing your Solidworks file. I learned some new skills with Fusion 360 this afternoon while changing the model to a 5-laser version.
The application I have in mind is to use this as an educational tool. It could show how different lenses makes the beams converge or diverge. This happens not only left-to-right but also up and down. 5mW lasers from China are cheap, and the cooler it looks, the longer it will hold the attention of a kid.

description.text: My first model that I designed and made myself, this is a pair of mounts that clip onto either side of the head of the Printrite or Colido DIY. There are 5 holes for 5.5mm LEDs on each part, for a total of 10. You will need to wire them up yourself, depending on the fwd voltage and current requirements of the LEDs you use, and the power supply you connect them to. My ultrabright white LEDs need a fwd voltage of 3.2V so each side has a set of three in series and a set of two in series, each with a resistor calculated for 20mA. I hope you enjoy this trivial thing that was more an exercise in modelling to specific dimensions rather than something I needed :)

Printer:

PrintRite DIY with Ramps1.4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I had to drill out the 5.5mm holes to get the LEDs in. I think that is because of the bridges as the holes are printed, but perhaps a higher resolution may help too.

description.text:
SPOOL HOLDER

  • SAVE - MATERIAL design
  • Doesn't need SUPPORT
  • Requires an external stand
  • Requires an internal rod
  • 4.5 mm internal radius
  • 26.25 mm external radius (it sould fit the most commons spools)

This spool holder is originally made for an Anet A8 printer, but it's fine for every other printer. Basically, it's an internal support for the spool which allows you to make it roll around a central metallic rod. Support for the rod is not included.

That curious shape allows to:

  • Use less material possible
  • Print WITHOUT ANY SUPPORT
  • Have a nice design

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The shape of this spool holder allows you to print it WITHOUT ANY SUPPORT.

Instead you WILL NEED RAFT to make it stable and sticking during printing. The 6 internal rays are intended to have an internal raft also if you choose to print it thin. Obviously they're intended to be removed after printing.
The shape should be simple enough to have a good final result with any printer; probably you will need to manage a little stringing if your parameters are not perfecly tuned.

These little Headphone Rests are perfect for hanging your headphones on a wall, it has a hole for a screw but it is possible to attach with strong double sided tape or a small command strip, or both using the screw for weight and the double sided tape to prevent it from moving around at all.

I use a construction paper build surface glued on with stick glue, and stick glue on top as well. This sometimes leaves paper residue on the printed object, this can be wiped of with a damp cloth.

I used 123D Design, and Selva3D to make this.

I started by taking some basic measurements of my headphones like the width of the headphone band and then in 123D Design I added some shapes and resized and merged them together, then I found a picture of some headphones which I uploaded to Selva3D which created a STL shaped like the picture. I then added the headphone shaped STL to 123D Design and resized and merged it with the headphone rest, then I exported it as a STL and put it into Makerbot Desktop.

This is a mini version remix of Braincodec's great design.

To make it easier I have resized the parts, 75%, needed from his version and added the new parts for the remix and accessories. It uses 6mm x 260mm rods from an old printer. For my version the knob will rotate the board but the board will not move vertically. All of the board clamping is done by the spring on the side opposite the knob side.

I allowed for clamping bolts for the legs but when I had it done I realized they are no longer necessary.

The component holder assembly easily snaps on and off. I used anti-static foam on the component holder that came with an IC chip.

Use a very light spring for the component holder pin. A bit heavier one for the clamping hand pin. The springs inside the knob are cut by experimenting with different lengths.

If anyone wants to use my accessories on braincodec's original design you could try scaling the parts 133.333%.

Use CA to glue the legs to the leg sliding clamping trays. Have the rods in place and try to not get glue on the rods. I didn't glue the rod end strip on. The optional tray can be used or you can print a second regular tray if you like.

description.text:
***Updates!

  • Now with spool lock for easy feeding, reloading and maintenance!!!
  • Code cleanup, comments, measuring diagram, smoothed clamp, parameterized. Use the "spool- ... -parmerterized.scad" files going forward.***

WIP - This is a Delta Spool Holder for my Griffin Pro XL. All other versions on Thingiverse would not fit my hard drive bearing so I created this one in openscad so that it could be used for any size bearing.

Measurements:

(diagram for entering measurements into parameterized files)

I used M4 screws and inserts for the platform, but it can be force fit by lowering tolerance and require no additional fasteners. I will add the tolerances I found to the code later, but each printer will be slightly different as tolerances are in the 0.5mm range for force fitting. (Currently using this adapter for drive bearing to spindle mount. Works well press fit: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:380636, I will replace with configurable if needed)

The design uses 3/4" pvc for the arms, this was to allow for custom fitting to my delta and reduce print time. It worked incredibly well. I do not recommend using anything smaller than 3/4" but if you do, the design is fully customizable. I will be cleaning up code and adding comments shortly.

This mount greatly improved z artifacts, the side spool design on my Griffin is a poor design choice that caused too much tension on the filament which showed up as ripples.

Warning! I am going to add a "lock" eventually but for now when loading the filament there is no longer any friction to hold the spool in place. This is perfect during printing as the forces on the filament are very small, but when manually pulling filament the spool will quickly spin sending rings of 1.75mm filament everywhere, it sucks but the results are definitely worth it. I usually place my spool on the side or floor while loading, then put it on the holder to minimize unwinding effect. Lock completed! No more mess.

Note: The "caps" are not required, they were originally created to hold the arms to the pvc but the tolerance is so tight that arms are force fit. They do look pretty though. :D

title: Acoustic Cups for Monoprice M560 Monolith Headphones (Magnetic)

description.text:
This is the perfect middle ground between the stock open and closed settings. The closed was tighter and more accurate, but completely lacked sound-stage and depth. The Open had great sound-stage, but lacked accuracy and had wobbled out bass.

These get a near perfect middle ground, maintaining the accuracy and punchy bass of the closed, while allowing a larger head-stage and balance from the open setting. This allows the headphone to remain fully closed and used in office environments as well.

Print with Support as the Magnet attach point is 3mm in depth.

Plus, made the outside look more fun and cool.

title: Rail Mount System and Raspberry Pi Mount- Qidi / Flashforge
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a rail-mount system for pretty much anything you want to mount to the top rear left of the Qidi Tech 1 (FlashForge Creator Pro Clone). The rail is custom designed, and you should be able to just attach it to any STL you have. The base mount is quite a bit longer than necessary (see photo above), but again, you can easily cut that to length using your favorite STL editor (TInkerCad is super simple for this).

I have also attached a separate STL file for a remix I did of Adafruit's Raspberry Pi 3 w/ 3.5" TFT screen case. I had some problems printing it with the mount attached, so I cut them into two parts and ended up welding them together using my 3D pen.

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print the mount upside down with supports under the press-fit corner connector. The rail needs to be attached to another model, so it depends on how your other model prints best.

Your tolerances need to be reasonably precise for the rail mount, especially on the bottom layer, however you can always sand that if necessary.

je me suis rendu compte que la taille de l'anneau est quand même très grand ( 24mm ) et que j'ai des doigts plutôt boudinés ( il faudrait que je fasse un régime ) . ce serai très long d'adapter le corps a chaque dimension j'ai donc créé des réducteur a insérer a l’intérieur de la bague . cela rajoute de l'épaisseur a l'anneau pour les plus petit taille mais c’est , je pense mieux que rien du tout .
j'en profite pour remercier les personnes pour leurs "likes" et téléchargement ( 53 downloads en moins de 24 heures a l'heure ou j’écris ces lignes ) , ça fait chaud au cœur .

I realized that the size of the ring is still very large (24mm) and that I have fingers rather puddled (I would have to do a diet). It will be very long to adapt the body to each dimension so I created gearbox to insert inside the ring. This adds thickness to the ring for smaller size but that is, I think better than nothing at all.
I take the opportunity to thank people for their "likes" and download (53 downloads in less than 24 hours by the time I write these lines), it's warm to the heart.

title: Ballistic experiment for  home and school

description.text:
The trajectory of a projectile launched under a certain angle at a certain speed can be calculated. However, it is much more fun to do a real ballistic desktop experiment.
We need a launch tube which can be set under an angle of choice, a projectile and a power source. In this Thing we use two standard 5mm ballpoint springs.We change the launch angle and measure the distance. The central question: At what angle is the distance at its maximum (don't shoot the cat).
https://youtu.be/UUE75MVYqds

description.text:
A modular case designed for the robo r1. Does not require any permament modification to the printer. It latches on the to the printer using hooks.

You need to cut these parts out on a laser cutter. But otherwise, it can be assembled by hand without any tools.

the dxf contains all the necessary files for the case itself. You can choose to arrange them however you want. The example pdfs show how I arranged the parts to be cut out on my laser cutter.

The window pdf is just an example of the acrylic cutout I used for my case. In reality, you can get any piece of acrylic that is larger than the window hole, but smaller than the case itself.

Instructional Video Here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mYnVwfppqzU

description.text:
This object tests the capability of the printer to print overhang from 40° to 75°.
Three curves including straight line, convex arc and concave arc are used to generate test form.
Previous overhang test often test with straight lines, which is essentially bridging instead of overhang. The convex surface would give the worst scenario of warping while printing overhang. Concave surfaces perform much better than convex.

Recommended to print without infill and top.
Let's see how you go.

remixed_from.title: Proteus - an OpenSCAD slope soarer design

description.text:
mashup of Proteus rear fuse and Motor mount for flying wing 28mm motor http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1699707

I accommodated plenty of clearance for a 2805 brushless with a 6045 prop. A channel to pass wires into the fuse was added. If it's on the wrong side, just mirror the part.

In order to pass the carbon spar through the fuse, you will need to drill through a non-structural bit... no big deal... A 3s 1500mAh fits well! curious how balance works out and no idea how it launch it yet!

comments.text: Have you tested it yet? Any mods required?
comments.author: PsicoPete

comments.text: I have not. BUT, there a a ton of really great flying examples on the Proteus page with video and pics. Seems to work well. There has been some speculation that ESC cooling is an issue. Some day I may modify/re-hack but for now seems to work just fine. You can mirror the part to swap the cable routing if it helps.

comments.author: superman33333

comments.text:
Started with https://www.banggood.com/DYS-D2826-2826-930KV-1000KV-1400KV-2200KV-Brushless-Motor-p-986316.html, 8x6 prop (will use folding prop later to improve gliding) and 1300mAh LiPo (1500mAh one with the same footprint did not fit the hollow in the nose). It flies really fast, enough power for starts, COG is OK witnout weight added.
I would however enlarge the channel for motor-ESC wires, it was almost impossible to put all three ESC wires in, and you may want to use connectors. I would also place the channel closer to the center of the fuselage to hide it in the recess created for motor bolts. Both left and right side channel would be OK and the unused one will let the cooling air out (some NACA air duct in the front) Unfortunately I was not able to do the changes in SketchUp.

comments.text:
Regarding launching this with the motor running on a flat field, apparently the best way is to hold it behind you with one hand at the front of the wing near to the fuselage. Apply full power and swing your arm rapidly over your head so it is launched at a shallow angle slightly above horizontal. Probably best to practice this a few times first without letting go. Better yet, get a friend to launch it the first time so you can react quicker.
That said, I have never tried this!
I launch my FX-61 wing by throwing it off the top of a slope without the motor running and then quickly applying power. I don't do much flat field flying.

title: Anet A8 Z axis end caps (noise)

description.text:
Z axis end caps for the Anet A8 - supposed to solve vibrating noise.

In order to mount them on the Z axis rods, I had to use a hair dryer and carefully heat them while pushing them onto the ends.

.stl == .obj, I used the .obj for my prints.

"Work in Progress" - I just moved the extruder for testing, but did not print again yet.

Test done - no problems observed.

comments.text: These caps should not be needed. If your threaded rods were vibrating, it means that your printer is a little out of wack. Adding these caps are just masking a problem that may lead to worse print quality.
comments.author: Eks_Whyzee

comments.text: The noise was due to resonance at certain heights - the length above the x axis was just right for the motor frequency.
comments.author: Eks_Whyzee

description.text:
This is a remix of DevDorian's Filament Guide Arm.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1915337

I really liked his original design but it seems like it was designed to go next to the LCD. I have my filament spool off to the side of my printer so I wanted the hold to be on the side as well. I ran into an issue where the holder would hit the upright z axis rod pieces so I made some tweaks and here we are. I also put in a version with a slit in it that I use to hold my auto levelling sensor wires on the opposite side of my frame to keep them away from other wires. I ran into an issue where the interference from the other wires was causing hiccups with the sensor.

title: Hictop Right Side X & Z Axis Lift Screw

description.text:
I do not have a picture with this installed on my printer. I did install it on my other hictop i3 printer that Is sold to someone. It worked perfectly. The picture of the orange and black printer has it installed. Sorry it is the only picture I have.

When assembled the Tension Arm pulls on the bearing that the x axis belt wraps around. when you tighten the m3 screw going through the Tension arm and the spring the belt will loosen. When you loosen the m3 screw that goes through the tension arm and spring the belt tightens. It worked better than I thought.

I am waiting until I have all of the parts printed for my new printer I am building until I install this upgrade on my printer. When I do I will create detailed assembly and installation instructions.

Here are some instructions if you want to try and install it before I get a chance to make the better instructions:

On the Z Right Printer inside the block sticking off of the right where the spring is, on the inside there is a M3 nylon lock nut that the screw that goes through the tension arm and spring screws into. How you get the nut into the recessed hole for the nut is you need to get like a 60mm long m3 screw and push it all the way through. with a pair of needle nose plyers go through the left side of the Z Right Printer and screw the m3 60mm screw into the nut. Once you have it on the screw pull, pull the screw to the right and rotate it until it seats into the recess hole for the nut, then pull it to lock it in. Then you can remove the M3 60mm screw. Find a m3 screw that works with the spring and the tension arm.

When putting the tension arm on I put a m3 fender washer between the Z Right Printer and the Tension Arm where they meet. you will notice a slot in the Z Right Printer where the tension arm slides against it. There are also m3 fender washers on the side of the screw head and nut. The m3 screw that goes through a m3 fender washer then the tension arm, z right printer with the belt bearing in the middle is a little tricky. Being as the bearing for the belt is made up of two bearings, I put a piece of blue painters tape around them to hold them together. You basically have to sew the m3 screw through the tension arm, the m3 fender washer, the z right printer, through the bearings, then through the other side of the z right printer, then the m3 fender washer, and finally through the other side of the tension arm capped off with another m3 fender washer and a m3 nylon lock nut.

You can get the springs here:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015CLFIYO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Gopro Kyosho RC car rear mount

description.text:
Another day another gopro mount.
When I got my gopro there was a few things I wanted to do with it,one was to put it on my r/c car and another was to mount it on a quadcopter that I will print, the quadcopter is a project for a later date so I started looking at mounting the camera to my 1/8th scale Kyosho nitro car (think its 1/8th scale).
I removed the rear arm that holds the shell in place and made a mount that incorporated this part all in one piece.
The arms for the shell are the original ones off the car and are 70mm apart to the outside of the pins.
I will take it out for a run as soon as possible and upload the vid of it in action.
Have fun people and If I don't see you before have a good new year ;)

Printed at 0.2mm layer hight at 40% fill in PLA.
when printed I removed the original pins that hold the shell in place and fitted them to the printed part.I pilot drilled a 1.5mm hole in the flat edge by the hole and fixed using the original screws.
I then placed it on the car and marked out the hole positions I wanted to use and pilot drilled these before fitting the screws.
If you do not pilot drill the holes you risk splitting the part with the screws.
I cut a small hole in the rear window to allow the arm through and replaced the thumb screws with M5x20mm cap head bolts as there is not much room available.
The shell can be fitted with the clip and fist joint fitted then put on the case and second joint with the other cap head screw, on mine there is enough room under the rear spoiler for the allen key to do up the screw. will depend what shell you have or if you run without you could probable use the original thumb screws

I designed this to make an enclosure for my Wanhao i3Plus out of three Ikea Lack tables.
It cosists of three different kind of parts and some hinges for the door.
It is very similar to other enclosure designs here on thingiverse, but made it mostly as an exercise in Fusion 360....

Corner 1 Top: 2 of this is required.
Corner 2 Top: Print one as it is, and one mirrored. (I only made one kind of this since mirroring is quite easy to do in Cura.)
The top corners are mounted between the legs and top of the Lack table. The screws enclosed with the table goes through the hole in the middle of the printed pieces.

Corner 1 Bottom: 2 of this is required.
Corner 2 Bottom: Print one as it is, and one mirrored. (I only made one kind of this since mirroring is quite easy to do in Cura.)

The bottom corners are screwed on to the cormers of the middle Lack table. After mounting them to the table, the plexiglass sides can slide into the slots on the printed corners. The Top Lack table is put on top of the bottom corners, and the plexglass sides can slide into the slots on the top corners. The legs of the top Lack table is then secured to the bottom corners with screws.

The Lac_Stack piece is used for stacking several Lack tables without any side panels. They are secured to the tabletop and lack legs using screws.

The hinges are used for the door of the enclosure. Each hinge requres 2 hinge ends and one midsection.

I am using this spoolholder inside the enclosure: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32204

Designed in Fusion 360

Designed in Fusion360.
Made a simple sketch and extruded to the correct height.

Hi
I first put the "Corner 2 Top"-piece flat and mutiplied it. Then mirrored along the x-axis. Final result was with the slots for the panels facing the front of the printbed, and the slots being on opposite sides of the two pieces (if that makes any sense :-) ). Same goes for the other corner piece that have to be mirrored.

description.text:
Of the many cable chains out there I couldn't find one that fit my needs. That is why I have designed this variation that allows for approximately 170 degrees of free movement. Along with this movement you are able to insert the wires AFTER the chain has been assembled.

There are three STL files in the download:

      - Cable Chain Link Branded  (Allows for full 170 degree movement)
      - Cable Chain Link_Restricted Movement ( limits the flex to only one direction)
      - Body Plug (Used to slide into the bottom of the links locking in the wires)
      - X_Motor Mount Cable_Bracket (Connects the chain to the X motor mount)

It is the printers choice which version of the chain they wish to use.

Details
EACH link extends the length of the chain by 28mm (2.8CM or 1.10236 in)
Inner clearance: 14.5mm wide and 11mm tall

Assembly
Once you have the links printed they will snap into each other by hand. It will be a SNUG fit to get then together but should move freely once popped into place.

Future Development
I am currently working on the brackets for mounting to the X axis carriage and motor mount for the A8.

EDIT 03/03/2017
I have uploaded a bracket for the connection to the X-Motor Mount on the A8. I am still it the process of PRINTING and TESTING this bracket. This means there may be changes done to it. If you are willing/wanting to print this bracket and report back with any issues I would greatly appreciate it.

EDIT 03/04/2017
X-Motor Mount Bracket has been changed again to allow for easier printing and a different sizing. There is an image added as well to demonstrate the suggested printing orientation.

author: cancer1910

title: parametric "halogen desk lamp" to LED strips retrofit

description.text:
parametric (you can choose how many rows and cols of led strip modules you want to use) retrofit module to turn ordinary halogen desk lamp (very popular here) to LED based lamp.

why?
Those lamps usually operate near their thermal limit. Often found in trash with burnt thermal fuse. If you replace the fuse with NC bimetal thermal switch they get new life. I usually used 50C or 70C switch because temps above degrade the transformer housing plastic.
This turns to be insufficient to drive 20W halogen bulb they are fitted with.
If you disassemble such lamps you often find embritteled and yellowed plastic. I use fair amount of ABS glue to glue broken stuff inside and reinforce everything.

Those lamps are cheap and many people own several broken ones.

so here is LED strip retrofit. LED's consume far less power and make whole thing very eternal and operating in sane temperature ranges.

features of the script
1)You can pick any X and Y size of the led strip, number of modules etc.
2)small box to hide rectifier bridge and capacitor

you will need rectifier bridge (5A shottky diodes from broken computer PSU's are excellent) and capacitor - if you want flicker-free lamp.

check total wattage of modules you plan to install (per module - usually it is 0.24W for regular or 0.72W for 5050 ) - try to not exceed 10W if you want long life of the lamp .

example is for 14 cheap modules, 0.24W each , 3.36W total. not stunning bright but good enough for night reading. if using 5050 modules it total will be 10.08W which should be brighter than original lamp.

ah. final note - do not bother with original glue of the LED strips.
Use nail lacqueer , abs glue or even superglue to fix the strips.
I used wood clips and hard sponge against all modules to make them all flat and even .

enjoy

description.text:
Stutzen für die Titan Radiallüfter der 75xx Baureihe.

Empfehlung: Titan B7530M12C (Amazon - ebay)

Den Stutzen gibt es mittlerweile in 5 Größen:

  • BBQ-Guru kompatibel (2 Stück - O-Ringe 25mm x 2,5 mm)
  • G 3/4"
  • G 1"
  • G 1 1/4"
  • 30 mm (2 Stück - O-Ringe 25mm x 2,5 mm)

Stutzen und Radiallüfter können ineinander gesteckt werden.
Die Steckverbindung am besten mit Klebstoff sichern.

Für den BBQ-Guru kompatiblen Stutzen werden 2 Stück O-Ringe (26 x 2,5 mm - ebay - Amazon) benötigt.

Der Lüfter hat bedingt durch seine schiere Größe einen hohen Luftdurchsatz, selbst im Stillstand.
Er eignet sich also nur für größere Grillgeräte/Smoker.

Funktionsfähige Gewinde sind nicht gerade leicht zu drucken. Eine einwandfreie Kalibration, gute Parameter und ausreichend Erfahrung sind unbedingt notwendig.

Noch ein kleiner Tipp am Rande:
Es lohnt sich kaum sich ein Anschlusskabel selber aus Einzelteilen zusammenzulöten.
Am besten eine vorkonfektionierte Verlängerung (Amazon) kaufen und die Buchse abschneiden.

Wer meine Arbeit unterstützen bzw. das Teil in hochwertiger Qualität gedruckt haben möchte, möge sich bitte hier oder hier melden.

title: Lasercut Robo3D Top Load Clip-on Spool - 6mm MDF
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A lasercut MDF overhead filament spool rack that I whipped up in Visio to dispense filament from a solid and secure overhead position on my Robo3D printer. The design fairly conforms to the Robo3D chassis and clips right on. I bought a 1/2" PEI rod ($2.50 CDN) from my local plastic supply shop and it fits tight in one of the holes on the frame. The hole with the tick mark is a hair wider and a 1/2" rod would easily pass through. You may use whatever means you prefer to secure the rod, depending on the materiel from which it is made.

Formatted for cutting on 6mm MDF sheet (or other substitute material) cut to 24" x 18" (Arch C sheet size) - I do all my work on an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG file that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

For the DE9 serial connector, I used a ttl to DE9 serial converter, which I had lying around. Any should do, since the DE9 connectors are pretty standard.

This design is relatively easy to print compared to some threaded 2-piece designs out there.

description.text: Cura allows base and cover to be assembled prior to printing. This was done in the G code file, so it prints all at once. After removing all supports and raft, carefully flex hinge to break it loose. The interior is filled with 2 small pieces of foam that put mild pressure on the filament to wipe it clean just prior to entering the extruder. When the foam wears, just rotate it 90 degrees or flip the faces front to back to get new cleaning surfaces.

description.text:
I split the original model from MakerBot since it was too large for my printer.

Just print:

1 x Top
1 x Bottom
2 x Connector

Unless you have a printer with a very large print area, you will probably need to put the top part at an angle, so you can take advantage of the z-axis space.

The connectors are for the two holes in each part, in some cases they fit so tight that no glue is needed, but even if using glue, they help keep the parts aligned while the glue dries.

I recommend gluing the parts for maximum strength.

description.text:
This is a two piece glass bed holder designed specifically for the Mendel90. I wanted a nice way of storing spare glass bed sheets, and I incorporated my design into existing fixture holes on the Mendel90.  
This glass bed holder ties directly into the existing 4 holes on the side of the gantry that are for optional bed fan. I do not use the bed fan on my printer, so I chose to take advantage of these already-drilled holes.  
This glass bed holder is designed to hold 3X .125" (3.175mm) thick glass sheets at the standard glass bed sheet size. It can also hold the 2mm thick glass sheet that came with the Mendel90 kit from Nophead.  
The design is composed of two pieces (for print simplicity) and is held together by 3X M4x16mm screws (I had spares of these from my kit). The design is held to the gantry by using the existing M4 screws that were present for the fan shield.

remixed_from.author: Ashtarius87
remixed_from.title: Right Melee Arms for Garin's Dreadnought

description.text:
I was a bit disappointed by the lack of an accurate claw for the, uh, Really Angry Dreadnoughts and the Psychically Proficient Bookkeepers in Dreadnoughts of the "Winged Heavenly Beings of Life Juice" chapter.

I would just like to note that I got the dimensions from Garin's MK II model and is meant to partner with MatttKing's Psycher files and Ashtarius87's Right Melee Arms and fit together all nicely. These files can be found under the "Remixed From" section to the left, if you don't already have them.

Another note, for legal purposes: I did not scan anything in the making of this Thing. I looked at images on the product's official site to get the overall shape. Everything was done freehand in SketchUp Make. My intention is not to detract business from the official site. If you can, support the company by spending $46.25 (USD) on the official model just to get this one bit.

Really, though, who is going to do that? If you just want to convert an existing model, don't spend $46.25 for a claw. That's just irresponsible. You should, however, support Gee Dubbya because the sculpts they put out are sometimes quite good*.

*As in "Hard to replicate and print, while sometimes being of great quality but not as good as Eff Dubbya, you know?".

title: Tablet Stand - works with iPad 2 and iPad Air

description.text:
The idea behind the original by Gizmoguyar is exactly what I was looking for as it enables the iPad to be supported at two different angles in both portrait and landscape orientaion. However, I found a few problems which this remix is designed to fix.
  • In the original, the connector piece had 'prongs' which were longer on one side than the other (Maybe because I scaled the original by 25.4 in Netfabb as I use millimetres rather than inches as my default measurement but whatever, the prongs stuck out on one side and not the other).
  • I wanted each of the main side pieces to have the shiny side, (the face printed next to the glass surface of my build platform), to be on the outside. In the original, one STL is used for both sides which does not allow this.
  • Maybe not strictly necessary but I wanted a little bit more support to keep the sides parallel to each other.
  • The connector piece on the original was way too tight for me as its prongs were the same size as the holes into which they fit on the sides. I made them a wee bit smaller - still tight but less sanding or filing required if at all.
  • I wanted to add some text to one of the side pieces and to do this, shortened the length of the connector prongs so that they do not go all the way through.
    • What you see here in the photographs has my name on it rather than the "iPad" text which is on the STL. Printed in Faberdashery PLA: Mellow Yellow and Spacemarine blue. The iPad is one of the newer "Air" models with an Apple case. I have also tried an iPad2 and that fits too - happy days!

Each of the two side pieces is designed to print at 0.3mm layer height. The connector and bar (two bars are required) are designed to print at 0.2mm. Print the each of the two sides with the 'flat' sides on the glass plate - the "iPad" text faces towards the glass and is only one layer deep. I used a 20% infill value which worked well.
All three connectors push fit into place reasonably easily although a rubber mallet comes in useful to bring everything into the home position nicely!

print_settings.Notes:: Taulman 910

description.text:
Similar to the Ü180, Über Design has come out with another free 3D printable quad!

Designed to be a small, brushless Tiny Whoop replacement, the Ü75 is an incredibly fun micro to fly around. Throw in a buck-boost converter and you got yourself a true indoor quad capable of tame flight on 1S lipos and thrilling speed on 2S lipos.

Recommended build parts here:
PikoBLX or other 20x20 FC
BR1103 Motors or BR0703
Racerstar 4-in-1 6A ESC
or BR1103 + 4in1 Combo
FPV AIO
Pololu Buck Boost
46mm Propellers
Rx of your choice (I use XM+)

Print all parts flat and at 100% infill in NYLON (Taulman 910 or Taulman 645 for best results). If you cannot print nylon, try PETG or ABS reinforced with CA. I wouldn't bother with any other material as they are either too flexible (TPU or TPU blends) or too brittle (PLA).

Currently a work in progress. A custom fitted Pod is in the works so stay tuned!

Printer:

Folgertech i3 2020

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Best results in Taulman 910. Taulman 645 is also acceptable but slightly more flexible.

print_settings.Notes:: This model provided several successful prints without supports.  I used Hatchbox Blue filament. It should fit snug around the ignition shaft.

description.text: I picked up a used 2004 Kymco Agility 125 scooter last summer. After the first month the ignition cap came loose because a tab broke off. This was a great opportunity to solve a real world problem with 3D printing. The process was pretty straight forward. I had to make 3 prototypes in getting the measurements just right. I doubt there will be many prints made of this item, but at least at some point in the future it will substitute a broken part. If you happen to print one for your own scooter, drop me a line.

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4m

Infill:

30%

Notes:

This model provided several successful prints without supports. I used Hatchbox Blue filament. If the print doesn't fit in on the scooter you can try to file down high areas that go around the shaft. If that doesn't work, try scaling down the print slightly. It should fit snug around the ignition shaft.

I was working at the Foundry Makerspace and wanted to provide an example of a real world 3D printing problem for students in the Robotics Club. To help them understand the design process I brought in the original cap and used calipers to measure every nook of the part. I then used Sketchup Make to model the par highlighting key steps. Instead of using 3D text, I thought I would go high-tech by using standard icons for the lock and power positions.

When I was finished I exported it out as an STL file. Another colleague had just purchased and received a Delta Printr Go 3D printer. I had told him about it during my NYC World Maker Faire trip on 10/1/16-10/2/16.

It took a couple of prototypes because of slight variations in printed material. After the 3rd try it the part fit perfectly. I was impressed that the icon showed up on the print.

comments.text: All, I am sorry for the delay in addressing this.  I uploaded an update for Metric (second STL file listed), which should be XY Dia = 35.7188mm and Z Height = 20.2652mm.  Please understand that there is an inherent variation in 3D printers in all directions, material cooling/expanding, etc.  Feel free to adjust as necessary, which I expected others to do to match the interior diameter size.  It is a snug fit.  Also be aware that the 3 clips are precarious because of the 3D print method.  It seemed to work best as ABS.  Using some type of finishing coat might help strengthen the material.

author: the_nerdling

description.text:
Terra Mystica Insert

It always turns out that our favourite games are the ones that take the longest to setup, so my goal was to reduce the set up time for Terra Mystica and make it easier to keep the table organised. Commonly used resources like coins, workers and terrain tiles have two seperate trays so that they can be more easily shared across a large table and are in neat fitting trays so that they can be easily passed around.

Instructions:
Print 2x Terrain Tiles and Workers
Print 7x Player Components
Pint 2x Coins
Print 2x Favour Tokens
Print 1x Everything Else

The town tiles, bonus tiles and favour tokens all fit neatly under the others and are angled for easier viewing and there is a large hole at the top end for easy removal. There are also specifically the number shown that are used while playing the game. in the case of the bonus tiles you can just put the ones you aren't using back in the box and it is obvious which ones are available for players to select when they pass. The favour token trays have finger and thumb holes for easy removal from the box, once you have removed one tray all of the others come out quite nicely.

Frustratingly not everything divides perfectly, i refer specifically to the workers (Wooden cubes). They all fit except 1 which in my game i have placed in with the magic discs as i prefered putting them in there to any way that i could have made them fit in the insert.

This does not include allowances for any expansion packs.

If you have any requests or suggestions for modifications feel free to ask me and i can see what i can do.

comments.text:
Hi,
I tried to print this with 0.8mm nozzle to achieve faster print and avoid hours of printing. But I'm facing some tollerance issues (eg. terrain tiles does not fit). So I have two requests:
1) could you please send me a "custom" version of the pieces with an offset of 0.5/0.6mm on "tiles/cards holes" (favour, cities, etc)?
2) could you split the bonus + city board into two pieces? Because it does not fit into my print area :(
I don't want to bother you, so if you have no enough time you can send me 3D models and I will edit them and proceed to print :)
I hope to hear from you soon :D

author: keegan01

description.text:
toy space shape blocks for early learning into space exploration

created with xyzmaker

Everybody is curious about the stars in the sky. So, let's begin our DIY to build our Newtonian Telescope.

For basic ABCs, you might google "Newtonian telescope".

This project may last for a month long, from 1st March to 31st March, 2017.
(2017.3.14) I have printed all the parts uploaded, the next step is assembling them together. Currently, in my mind, the most difficult tast would be the adjustment of the light path.

1.Materials

Although this is a DIY telescope, some parts involved are still from local market, such as: (here is mine, and you can choose parts with different parameters)

1 A primary concave mirror, diameter = 114 mm, focal length = 900 mm, thickness =14 mm
2 A secondary mirror, elliptic shape, minor axis length = 23 mm
3 A pipe, diameter = 130 mm, length > 750 mm
4 A eye piece, diameter= 32 mm, focal length = 12.5 mm
5 Screws, nuts and springs

2. Main Step

Herein, the diy here may be devided into some steps, such as:
a) Assemble the Primary Concave Mirror into the pipe;
b) Assemble the Secondary Mirror into the pipe;
c) Assemble the Eyepiece into the pipe;
d) Assemble the Pipe (with Primary, Secondary mirrors and eyepiece assembled) to a tripod
e) asjust the light path.

These steps may not contain in this diy.
f) design a connector between the eyepiece and a Digital Camera.
(find one in thingiverse: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106657)
g) equip a finderscope
(take a laser pointer instead)
h) some equatorial device
Simplified Scheme for a Newtonian Telescope

author: dseelbach80

title: ZTE Phone Bracket for Tetrix - FIRST Tech Challenge

description.text: This was part of an after school FIRST Tech Challenge Robotics Club. The students had limited time and equipment. I provided assistance in guiding them through the process of Design Thinking. The goal was to create a bracket that would hold a USB adapter tight against the ZTE phone they had been using to control their robot. This was a good exercise to explain the reverse engineering process. It helped students observe existing items and how to model a new part to serve a need.
NGSS

This part was created because the students noticed that the usb connection on the ZTE were getting a lot of wear and tear.  The connection and cables were get a lot of use because of students connecting the phones to computers to upload the scripts and then they would connect them back up to the robot controller.  The classroom had plenty of 90 degree usb connectors, but they were not getting used because of the weak connection.
I worked with a few students to use calipers to model the brackets in Sketchup Make.  For the phone clips I scanned them on a flatbed scanner showing students alternative ways to get digital data into Skechup.  From there I traced the edge and modeled the curves.

Have students devise a way to recreate a different way to secure phones to their FTC robot. Even though the model has been built and fits the phones just fine, this could be adapted for other types of phones. It is a great exercise to help students develop Design Thinking Skills (Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype, Test = https://dschool.stanford.edu/.) It helps if students already have a background in 3D modeling. The ones I was mentoring during this afternoon session (10th & 11 grade students), did not have any background. I only had time to show them the steps of my Design Thinking Process. I encouraged them to load the free software on their laptops and teach themselves with the plethora of videos on the web. If students have a strong enough 3D modeling background and enough interest, they should be able to recreate a model with a brief lesson in using the caliper.
  • I pulled together all the original parts that were needed in one place. I asked students what worked and what didn't.
  • I then provided students with digital calipers to measure parts in mm.
  • After some of the measurements were taken, I began to model the part. Students were busy with other robotics tasks and I would have them stop back in at various stages.
  • The first part I created was the USB Bracket that connected to the Tetrix hole location.
  • We then exported the STL from Sketchup using the STL Export extension. When the print was done students could do a comparison to the original. What we did not realize is that the punches on the original did not fit the hole configurations on the Tetrix parts. We had to go back to the model and correct the hole locations. This was done by measuring an actual Tetrix strut.
  • Once a part is printed it is good to discuss potential shape changes due to material expansion, errors in measuring, or printer calibration. It was also a good lesson to test the strength of the parts using a force scale and a metal bar to break the parts.
  • If you find a part that is difficult to model it helps to scan it on a flatbed scanner. You can then import the image into Sketchup and use the TAPE MEASURE to uniformly scale the entire model from a known measurement.
    • An alternative option for this exercise would be to have students make prototypes out of cardboard, foam, wood, glue / hot glue gun and scan them in on a flatbed scanner. This is a quick and easy way to use mixed media in the design process. Some students might prefer to get their ideas out in cardboard and they can quickly test how it interacts with a phone.

It would help to have the following on hand if you are using this Lesson for a FIRST Tech Challenge Robotics Club.
  • Phone used to control the FTC Robot
  • Tetrix part
  • Digital Caliper
  • Modeling materials (cardboard, foam, wood, glue / hot glue gun, sketchpad)

• Surface Modeling
  • Critical Thinking
  • Collaboration
  • Creativity
  • Communication
  • Design Thinking
90 minutes
If you have a different phone you could download the USB Phone Bracket so that students could "remix" the model to fit the USB connector location on a different phone.

4Cs Rubric and NGSS Connections A. Collaboration (E6, M5, E7),
  • Student always demonstrates an ability to work with others and encourages others to participate.
  • Student sometimes demonstrates an ability to work with others.
  • Student rarely demonstrates an ability to work with others.
  • Student does not wish to work with others.
    • B. Communication (S8, E2, E3, M3 & E4, E5):
  • Student always demonstrates strong communication skills in the terminology presented in the lesson.
  • Student sometimes demonstrates strong communication skills in the terminology presented in the lesson.
  • Student demonstrates a basic understanding of terminology and has difficulty communicating key concepts.
  • Student does not have an understanding of terminology and needs assistance in explaining key concepts.
    • C. Creativity (E6, S1, S3, S4, S6, Additionally M4, S2, S5):
  • The design approach contains strong design qualities that represent a thoughtful approach to solving the design challenge.
  • The design approach contains average design qualities that solved the design challenge.
  • The design approach solved the design challenge absent of additional design considerations.
  • A clear and cohesive design approach was absent in the model.
    • D. Critical Thinking (E6, M5, M6, M7, M8, S1, S3, S4, S6):
  • The student demonstrated an strong work flow process in the project addressing all the design objectives.
  • The student demonstrated an average work flow process in the project addressing few the design objectives.
  • The student demonstrated a weak work flow process in the project addressing only one design objectives.
  • The student did not demonstrate a work flow process and addressed non of the design objectives.

description.text:
This design replaces the single-reel holder for the Mendel90. There are two mirrored halves that sit on top of the gantry that hold a .5" (13mm) rod between them.  
The right piece also acts as a spacer for the Melzi board (replaces the two small white ring spacers). This allows for the piece to be secured to the gantry. The left piece also has screw clearance holes allowing it to be secured to the left gantry, but I chose not to secure it at this time.  
I'm currently using a .5" steel rod that sits between the two pieces. The steel rod is 12.25" long. Due to the Melzi board locating this design, only reel diameters of 8" or less can be used with this design without any modifications.

title: Pi ZeroW case with screws and CS mount

description.text:
Slight remix of bobtidey's excellent design (I love the camera cable slot and the fact its OpenSCAD!)

I've basically changed it to take m2.5 (id) x 3.5 (od) x 4mm long knurled inserts, made it slightly taller, removed the screw countersink (as I plan on using allen hex heads) and formatted the code a bit.

I made the base a bit taller to accommodate the ZeroW and larger HDMI cables. Made the holes through the base M3-sized so that the M2.5 bolts have some wiggle room when trying to line up with the M2.5 knurled inserts (I can never get them in straight!) Also added a chamfer on the supports to add some strength at the base to stop them snapping off if you apply too much lateral force.

Test prints fit fine with 8mm long M2.5 bolts.

I plan on making another version with the screw holes that go all the way through to be bolted together without the knurled inserts, and maybe use M3 nuts & bolts (you can widen the Pi holes a bit with a tap or a self-tapping screw) as they're easier to find than M2.5

Added a new version with a C/CS lens mount (and M12 mount within it) with the camera module inside the case.

title: Yuneec Q500 CGO3 External Antenna Mount

description.text:
Most Q500 pilots know moving the camera WiFi 5.8GHz antenna from inside the CGO3 camera will increase your video range. There are lots of articles and YouTube videos detailing the mod. Most of them required you to drill a hole or otherwise modify the body to mount the antenna.

I wanted a way to both mount the antenna without drilling or zip tying, and was removable if needed. After trial and error, I came up with this.

After printing, sand the bottom to match the curve of your Q500 body mounting point. I glued hook and loop (soft side) to the Q500, and the hook side to the mount. I actually used a battery strap cut up to fit. Just use something with good grip.

After many flights, it stays firmly attached. I mounted it with the SMA mount to the front, simply so that the bottom plate provides leverage to help keep the antenna from pulling it loose.

remixed_from.title: Layer cooling fan duct for Da Vinci 1.0 3D printer with the E3Dv6 mod

title: Da Vinci Duo 2.0 Dual E3D conversion no drilling no cutting

description.text:
Update: Added an E3D themed fan cover for the repurposed Da Vinci 40mm fans, also added a version of the cable chain mount that uses M3 heat sets instead of sliding in a nut.

Ok, so this is a remix of several different things all put together to provide for a drop in, no drill, no cut dual E3D extruder mount. Please refer to the original designs for other possible installation tips as most have not changed. I have loaded two designs for the backing plate and Hotend Mount. One design is a bare bones basic, the other is a remix I'm using on my 1.0 that gives me an integrated chain mount on the backing plate and PTFE guides on the Hotend base. The PTFE guides are designed to use the existing rubber mounts installed in your original Da Vinci extruder. I have installed the original PTFE guides from mine as well as a few pieces of cable carrier chain for examples. I have also included a layer cooling fan duct (you'll need to print two) that allows the use of your original cooling fans once you make the changes in your Repetier firmware.

I used the original height and location from the 1.0 E3D mount I remixed which positioned the extruder at nearly the same height and position as the original on my 1.0, my hope is this will produce the same results on the 2.0. Unfortunately I did not have two E3D extruders available to test fitment and function.

Installation:

Layer Cooling fan ducts:
Install these first before everything else. Use one #6 metal screw in each (they are designed to fit either side). Inner screen holes will line up with the bottom inner stepper motor mounting holes. Install original cooling fans from your Da Vinci extruder. some trimming or shaping of outlet may be required to clear the extruder tip(again didn't have one available for testing)

Don't forget your fan cover to let everyone see you upgraded to E3D.. :)

Hotend mount:
Required hardware...
-8x M3 brass heat set threaded insert for plastic (McMaster No. 94180A331)
-8x M3 washer (i.e. McMaster No. 90965A130)
-4x M3x16mm phillips machine screw (i.e. McMaster No. 92005A126)
-4x M3x25mm phillips machine screw (i.e. McMaster No. 92005A130)

Heat set four M3 brass inserts into the backing plate and four into the back side of the hot end base.
Mount your E3D hotends to the base with 4 M4 x 25mm machine screws and the cap. Take care when fitting the hot ends to make them as even as possible. There is a small amount of play on the carriage for final leveling.
Line up the backing plate on the stepper motor side of the carriage with the hot end base on the extruder side. Start the top two M3 x 16mm screws but leave them loose to allow the fan shroud to slide in. Insert the remaining two M3 x 16MM thru the fan shroud and hot end base threading them into the backing plate. You can not snug up all 4 screws till final alignment.

Next install the cooling fans on the fan shroud provided with your E3D kit.

You can now attach the circuit board with 2 #6 metal screws(they fit in the board tight but do fit )to the block on the backing plate.

Chain Mount:

Additional parts required:
Stock 10x15mm drag chain segments - I bought mine from Bluesky on Amazon, others may work as well. You'll need 22 links (about 18 inches [450mm]) and the post-end anchor.

two M4 x 8mm or 10mm machine screws and nuts to mount the chain end anchor to the fixed mount. Or use the new Heat set version and M3 screws instead..

Installation

Attach the drag chain anchor to the fixed mount with two M4 x 8mm machine screws and nuts. The nuts just slip into the rectangular slot. Remove the screws from the top right Z-axis slide mount, put the fixed mount over the holes and reinstall screws.

Attach the other end to the built in mount on the backing plate.
Feed your cables through and take the chain apart where you need to make connections. Reassemble and you're ready to go.

There is a lot of info and hopefully I didn't miss anything. Good luck to anyone that tries this and please let me know how it works for you.

Oh yea and please make sure you run your print bed leveling routine after installation. don't want to see any broken print beds..

Good Luck..

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0a

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

75%

Notes:

Most parts were printed with 2mm top, bottom, and sides and 75% infill for structure. Supports were only used on the backing plate to support the cable tie loop but may help for a better print on the fan shroud. The layer cooling fan duct will print correctly without supports if stood on the fan mount end.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text: Two separate tower sizes are available: one for standard polyhedral dice sizes and one for mini dice (or just for use as a prop). The smaller tower took exactly five hours to print on my Robo 3D at nearly 100% infill. For the larger of the two towers, a 20% infill value was used and it took exactly ten hours to print. I was pleasantly surprised at how few issues the full sized print had, especially considering it nears the maximum vertical axis print height possible for my printer. The low infill makes the tower surprisingly light, and it has already held up to several gaming sessions worth of dice throws.

print_settings.Notes:: Because of the weight of 1kg spools and the default layer orientation to remove the need of supports, I recommend three walls/shells plus some infill to ensure the part has sufficient strength for extended use.

title: MP Select Mini Reduced Spindle Rounder

description.text:
This is a redesign of Enzi1984's spindle rounder that is reduced in height and width to allow smaller diameter spools such as the Quarter Turn 5 Dollar Filament Spool Holder by 3DPRINTINGWORLD (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121407). It still works fine with standard 1kg spools.

UPDATE: I've added a modified version of the rounder that adds a raised bumper next to the printer. This corrects a problem with some spools that would migrate too far toward the printer and settle into the space between the rounder and the printer frame, potentially restricting the spool's movement.

Inspired by Enzi1984's MP Select Mini - Spindle Rounder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2036976

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Because of the weight of 1kg spools and the default layer orientation to remove the need of supports, I recommend three walls/shells plus some infill to ensure the part has sufficient strength for extended use.

description.text:
R.I.P Bill Paxton :( I thought of many different things to make as a memorial but the dog tags seemed the best fit.

The ones in the photo were cast in resin from the 3D print supplied here in the file, the print itself comes out a bit cleaner as I only made a one piece mold.

This is a memorial print, please do not use it for profit in any way shape or form, this includes prints. It's to remember a fallen hero, not make money off.

remixed_from.author: Tobi97l
remixed_from.title: Glass Bed Bracket for Anet A8

title: Glass Bed Bracket for Tronxy P802E

description.text:
Update 02: I added a spacer to put on the end of the screws. This will allow for better distribution of force applied to the glass by tightening the screws.

Also, I have noticed that there is no need to put these on all four corners. Just using two on opposite corners will suffice.

Update 01: One of the bottom tabs was not the proper thickness causing one of the screws to be too high when contacting the glass. This is now fixed and both tabs are the same thickness.

I remixed this bracket to add slots to hold nuts allowing longer usage by avoiding threading of the plastic which will wear out.
I also added a ring on the bottom for the bed tension spring.

Hardware to be used: M3 Bolt and Nut
